data.title: Las Matas de Santa Cruz
data.meta_description: Las Matas de Santa Cruz, also called San Jose de Las Matas, or Las Matas de la Sierra is a city in the Dominican Republic's Monte Cristi Province, located in the heart of the four provinces of the Northwest. It rests at 580 meters (1,900 feet) above sea level, on one of the branches of the Amina...
data.text:
Las Matas de Santa Cruz, also called San Jose de Las Matas, or Las Matas de la Sierra is a city in the Dominican Republic's Monte Cristi Province, located in the heart of the four provinces of the Northwest. It rests at 580 meters (1,900 feet) above sea level, on one of the branches of the Amina River. To the Southwest of the village is the small peak of Pico El Rubio (1430 metres 4,700 ft), forming the extremity of a chain.

About[]

Population: 3.000

Geography[]

Las Matas de Santa Cruz is located at 19.67133° N, -71.50629° E. According to the ONE, the municipality has a land area of 109.51 square kilometers (42.28 square miles). This municipality is limited to the north by the town of Castañuela, to the east by the town of Guayubín, to the southwest by the town of Partido, to the west by the city of Dajabón, and to the northwest by the city of Monte Cristi.

Locations

Popular neighborhoods include Barrio Lindo, Don Pastor, Santa Lucia, El Cayuco ("The canoe"), and La Mina ("The mine"), among others.

This municipality has three interlocked communities: Santa Cruz, La Horca, and Los Amaceyes,

Demographics

Population Year Change 2002 10,762 2010 10,559 2018 11,172

Resources[]

This town has gold mines and mahogany forests. Its rural sections were Rouviol, Gurabo, Maguana y Sabaneta, Los Montanes Icayagua, and Yaque.

Economy[]

The local economy is largely based on agriculture. It has an active trade, being able to count on private banks, the Agricultural Bank, the Reserve Bank, Copsano Cooperatives and Fondesa. Its greatest production is the cultivation of rice, bananas and livestock, as well as minor fruits.

In 1840, the area produced tobacco, coffee, leather, wax, and beef. Individuals cut and sold on their behalf, without permission, mahogany wood that was on the land of the State. The Secretary of State I.C. Imbert wrote to the Justice of the peace, on December 9, 1825, to stop this abuse.

Administration[]

This municipality was not allowed to elect a MP to the House of Representatives.

Sabaneta is the attic of San Jose de Las Matas.

In this municipality, one can find: the Yaque del Norte Basin Irrigation District, Agricultural Sub-Area of ​​Agriculture, Management 14 of the IAD, the Institute of Hydraulic Resources (INDRHI), and the Fernando Valerio Irrigation Board (it directs more than 5,000 users that are dedicated to the sowing of Rice, Bananas, minor fruits and livestock, which provides a total of 250,000 jobs and contributes 90% to the agricultural and livestock development of the area)
